context: Infection begins <a0_0><b5_0>when an organism successfully enters the body, grows and multiplies<b5_0/>.<a0_0/> This is referred to as colonization. Most <a1_0><b6_0>humans<b6_0/><a1_0/> are not easily infected. Those who are <a2_0><b7_0>weak, sick, malnourished, have cancer or are diabetic<b7_0/><a2_0/> have increased susceptibility to chronic or persistent infections. <a3_0><b8_0>Individuals who have a suppressed immune system<b8_0/><a3_0/> are particularly susceptible to opportunistic infections. Entrance to the host at host-pathogen interface, generally occurs through the mucosa in orifices like the oral cavity, nose, eyes, genitalia, anus, or the microbe can enter through open wounds. While a few organisms can grow at the initial site of entry, many migrate and cause systemic infection in different organs. Some pathogens grow within the host cells (<a4_0><b9_0>intracellular<b9_0/><a4_0/>) whereas others grow freely in bodily fluids.
